This is not a subtweet I swear! Just something I've been thinking about, and also the reason why a writer's got to be real special for me to read their WWII books

We all know "Nazi romance" is wrong, but if I see one more book that I call "Holocaust torture porn" I'm gonna yell

I love reading angst. I love a book that makes me cry. I love getting emotionally invested in characters who face real difficulty.

But the Holocaust is the *Holocaust.*

And if you're setting your story there, I want you to really really think about why.

I have real questions about whether historical fiction's love of WWII is really serving the "never again" purpose it thinks it is, or is it using Jewish suffering as an evangelical plot device that makes "Holocaust" an empty signifier for "big abstract tragedy"

So...idk, be gentle to each other. Ask your friends how they're doing. Give yourself breaks. If it feels like every basic task takes nineteen times more effort than it used to, you're not alone. 💜💜

Anyway, this is all probably early-morning whining, so I apologize for annoying the timeline.

But I just don't think people realize how much this past year has fucked us up.

My pandemic experience was fortunate by many metrics and I still worry it fundamentally broke my brain.

And it was hard before! My brain and I weren't on the best of terms before!

But I knew its quirks and I could navigate it. I'd had a lifetime of learning how to deal with my own peculiar brand of mental health.

I've had a couple months to figure this one out. And I haven't yet.

And the most frustrating part? The story is IN THERE. I can SEE IT. But I can't GET IT. Because of all the gunk and tar and dust and fucking debris these past 18 months have left surrounding my brain.

It's a damn paleontological excavation every time I try to write a sentence.

I'm making outlines, then I'm making level-two more-detailed outlines out of my outlines, and then I'm turning the outlines into prose.

This is not my ideal process. It sucks. It's just the only way I can scrape through the gunk surrounding my brain to get at the story in there.

To get creative work done, I am micromanaging the ever-loving shit out of every project.

Like, it's ludicrous.

There are post-its all over the walls. I've got thirty pages of handwritten synopsis.

I'm dragging myself out of bed ten minutes before my day job starts, collapsing on the couch at 5pm, falling asleep at 9:30 because my body physically will not stay awake.

(Yes, I'm talking to a doctor. Kindly refrain from offering medical advice on Twitter.)

This is all probably oversharing and not doing my career (such as it is) any favors, but...

I have never struggled so hard with the process of creating things as this past year.

And it's terrifying.

My debut was the book of my heart, and if I get this second book out in the world it's gonna be the book of my white-knuckled determination, I love it and I want y'all to love it too but it's the most difficult thing I've ever done

I know agents and authors feel different pressures, but LORD YES I've thought about quitting the writing game and just working my 9-5 pretty much every day these last 12 months

(I'm not gonna. I'm still in it. But oh my god it's hard.) https://t.co/StidzNXuUp

Anyway, this is more craft-related than most of my shower thoughts. Usually I'm thinking things like "remember the exact smell of Cici's Pizza Buffet in 2006?" But it's 9pm on a Tuesday and we get what we get, I guess.
In conclusion, you and your English teacher were both sorta right. The author might not have meant anything by it originally—or maybe they surprised themselves by how much they did mean.

Maybe some people can start with the concept. I can't! I always end up writing a didactic "issues story" when I do.

But for the books that mean something to me, that moment when the concept clicks is when I know revisions might be getting somewhere.

Did the Great Novelists set out to write a book about the Failure of the American Dream? I dunno.

Maybe they wrote a messy draft about a guy who threw fun parties, and when they were taking a shower halfway through the second draft they said "hold on a dang second"

The characters have to wander around in a messy fog for a while until I figure out what it is that actually interests them—and me.

You ask me what a book's about on a first draft and I will, invariably, give you the wrong answer.

For this book I'm working on now, it's loyalty, and what we are and aren't willing to compromise for it.

But I never know what the concept is going to be until about 2/3 of the way through a second draft.

Every project I've invested a significant amount of time in has an organizing concept that centers it for me.

For A TIP FOR THE HANGMAN, it was the idea of righteousness, and what we're capable of when we believe we're justified.

"The author's just writing a story," we said. "Maybe he just wants the walls to be blue, it doesn't have to be a big thing. It's just a BOOK."

I don't think of myself as an issues writer, so to some degree I agreed.

BUT.

Thread of shower thoughts that no one asked for:

You remember in high school English, when your teacher would sum up a novel by theme? Like, "the death of the American dream," or "the animalistic nature of mankind."

And we all grumbled that was BS?

Kit's life has so many fascinating facts packed into such a short span, and I tried to explore as many of them as I could in my book!

As a birthday present to Marlowe, consider giving A TIP FOR THE HANGMAN a try—I think he'd appreciate it. https://t.co/Zxf4HtsZar

5. Marlowe was great buds with Sir Walter Raleigh (of "Raleigh, North Carolina" fame), who ran a semi-secret atheist club called The School of Night.

This:
A) Did not do much for the "Kit's an atheist" rumors
B) Is why I love Kit the Vampire in Only Lovers Left Alive so much https://t.co/3nGYUYShry
(4.5: Greene would go on literally four years later to write a play that is 100% a ripoff of Tamburlaine, which nobody enjoyed, so make of that what you will.) https://t.co/sK0rAzUvLR

4. Marlowe had a bit of a reputation: brawler, heretic, atheist, sodomite (their term). 

His plays pissed off some contemporaries for that reason. Robert Greene called Tamburlaine an "impious instance of intolerable poetry [by a] mad and scoffing poet," which, OK, Greene. https://t.co/kdlMFszWDi

3. There's lots of "Marlowe faked his death and became Shakespeare" conspiracies out there (😑), but in 2016, new evidence surfaced that Kit and Will might actually have collaborated on parts of Henry VI Part 1.

https://t.co/ucQz3GKwwh

2. Marlowe didn't just write plays! He was the first person to translate Ovid's elegies into modern language.

He also wrote a v. sexy poem about a Greek guy getting romanced by Poseidon God of the Sea, which I nodded to in A TIP FOR THE HANGMAN bc I love it so much. https://t.co/P09sfH8Ndz

1. Marlowe's life was full of mystery—we're not even sure how he spelled his name! There's at least a dozen variants floating around: Marlow, Morley, Marley, Merlin, Marlin, and so on.

Marlin is my favorite, for obvious reasons. https://t.co/E5tCAYOu6X

All this to say, if it's getting harder than before, I see you.

And if it hurts when you see whatever your version of the tree is, know there's nothing wrong with you for hurting.

Failing to thrive under unnatural conditions doesn't make you a failure.

(7/7)

I don't know if we'll learn from this. If this is the launching pad for a public health reckoning. God knows it should be.

But grief also saps hope, and it's hard to see a reassuring way out of something like this.

(6/7)

Claudius tells Hamlet prolonged grief is "a fault to heaven, a fault against the dead, a fault to nature," and while Claudius is a dick, he's not WRONG. 

It's the same pain, in the same words, over and over, broken from all reference points in time. It's *not* natural.

(5/7)

And it's the same grief. Every day. After a certain point, it still hurts, but there's nothing new to say.

It's exhausting to talk about. But it's still there.

(4/7)

With other kinds of grief, they tell you to lean on others. Borrow strength from them.

But we're all having this grief at the same time. Others much worse than us.

There's nowhere to lean without feeling guilty about the extra weight you're adding.

(3/7)

The feeling's in a different key, but it's similar to when I hear a song that reminds me of my late grandfather, or when I drive past the house of my neighbor who died in a car accident.

It's grief.

(2/7)

I just looked outside and felt like somebody punched me in the stomach.

The tree outside my living room window is in the exact same state of growth as when this all started.

I took a picture of my view that first day.

There's even a bird sitting on the same branch now.

(1/7)

And SO MANY people rallied around this book.

My author heroes said nice things about it.

@meunierjames performed the audiobook so beautifully I wanna give him an Oscar.

Mike Windsor pulled out a cover To. Die. For.

So many other people. My god.

There's two reasons that's actually true.

One: Kit Marlowe got in my head and wouldn't leave me alone until I got his story right. He's more real to me than many currently-living people by now, and I hope I did you proud, Kit.

Two: I've got the best team in publishing.

I started this book in the back of my travel journal on a plane from Dublin to Detroit in 2013.

In the ~8 years since, it's taken so many shapes. Gotten so many rewrites.

But in my heart I kept telling myself "don't quit on this baby. This is the one people are gonna read."

A TIP FOR THE HANGMAN is out in the world today, and frankly I still can't believe it.

I'm so proud of this messy, twisty, fun, dark, honest book, and I'll always love its protagonist with my whole heart.

I really, really hope you love it too.

we just...slashed people's abilities to earn a living

separated them from all their support systems

made the unimaginable stress of pandemic control a question of "personal choice"

and then...expect everyone to...carry on meeting their deadlines?

this isn't sustainable

yes, I know it's been 330 days. that doesn't make it sustainable.

it just means it's been unsustainable for a long time.

This is an accountability tweet more than anything.

Now every time I search my book I'll KNOW I shouldn't be, and hopefully the guilt will work.

Every reader is entitled to their opinion! Please have opinions! I yearn for you to have opinions! Positive! Negative! Otherwise!

It's just too late for me to do anything with them, and swimming in feedback I can't act on is melting my final remaining brain cell!

It's nine days from my debut book release and I'm finally setting up the guard rails.

Blocking Goodreads. Turning off my Google alerts. Weaning myself off searching my book on Instagram every 11 minutes.
